required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: The Safety and Efficacy of a SinuSonic Intervention
clinical_study.official_title: SinuSonic Study for Adults With Nasal Congestion

brief_summary.textblock: This study aims to test the safety and effectiveness of the SinuSonic device on adults with moderate to severe nasal congestion. SinuSonic is a medical device that utilizes sound and pressure combined with normal breathing to relieve nasal congestion. This device is held over the nose for 3 minutes. This study will use patient responses to measure how effective SinuSonic devices are in treating these moderate to severe congestion in adults. The study will consist of 40 subjects at the Medical University of South Carolina and will take place over the course of 4 to 6 weeks starting with a baseline assessment.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in Total Nasal Symptom Score (TNSS) at 4 to 6 Weeks
primary_outcome.time_frame: Total Nasal Symptom Score (TNSS) at 4 to 6 Weeks
primary_outcome.description: Change from baseline to week 6 in subject congestion symptom severity, as measured by the Total Nasal Symptom Score (TNSS, range 0-3). Where 0 indicates no symptoms, a score of 1 for mild symptoms that are easily tolerated, 2 for awareness of symptoms which are bothersome but tolerable and 3 is reserved for severe symptoms that are hard to tolerate and interfere with daily activity. TNSS is calculated by adding the score for each of the symptoms to a total out of 15.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Peak Nasal Inspiratory Flow Test (PNIF Test)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Peak Nasal Inspiratory Flow Test (PNIF Test) score at 2 Weeks
secondary_outcome.description: Change from baseline to week 2 in subject nasal airway obstruction, as measure by the Peak Nasal Inspiratory Flow Test (PNIF Test). The PNIF is used to diagnose the patency of the nose.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Sinonasal Outcome Test 22 (SNOT-22) Total Score
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Sinonasal Outcome Test 22 (SNOT-22) Total Score at 4 to 6 Weeks
secondary_outcome.description: Change from baseline to week 6 in subject symptoms and functioning, as measured by Sinonasal Outcome Test - 22 (SNOT-22). SNOT-22 is a subject-completed questionnaire that consists of 22 questions. Each item is rated as follows: 0=no problem, 1=very mild problem, 2=mild or slight problem, 3=moderate problem, 4=severe problem, 5=problem as bad as it can be. The total score can range from 0-110, 0 being the best and 110 being the worst.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Visual Analog Scale (VAS) score at 4 to 6 Weeks
secondary_outcome.description: The visual analog scale (VAS) for rhinosinusitis is used to evaluate the total severity. The subject is asked to indicate on a VAS the answer to the question: "How troublesome are your symptoms of rhinosinusitis?" Subject will assess Nasal symptoms using a 10 cm Visual Analog Scale for each symptom, 0=not troublesome and 10 = the worst imaginable. The disease can be divided into Mild, Moderate and Severe based on total severity VAS score (0 to 10 cm): Mild = VAS 0-3 Moderate = VAS > 3-7 Severe = VAS > 7-10

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Nasal Obstruction and Septoplasty Effectiveness Scale (NOSE Scale)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Nasal Obstruction and Septoplasty Effectiveness Scale (NOSE Scale) score at 4 to 6 Weeks
secondary_outcome.description: Change from baseline to week 6 in subject nasal congestion severity, as measured by the Nasal Obstruction and Septoplasty Effectiveness Scale (NOSE Scale). The NOSE scale is a subject-completed questionnaire that consists of 5 questions. Each item is rated as follows: 0=not a problem, 1=very mild problem, 2=moderate problem, 3=fairly bad problem, 4=severe problem. The total score can range from 0-100, 0 being the best and 100 being the worst.

other_outcome.measure: Safety Descriptive About Occurrence of Adverse Events
other_outcome.description: Safety will be evaluated by the Adverse events occurence

other_outcome.measure: Evaluation of Results of General Physical Examination
other_outcome.description: Collection of safety data throughout the whole study period

arm_group.description: SinuSonic Device used twice a day for four to six weeks.

intervention.description: A medical device that utilizes sound and pressure combined with normal breathing to relieve nasal congestion

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
1. Adults â‰¥18 years of age
2. Complaints of nasal congestion present for 2 weeks or more and a qualifying nasal congestion score of >5 (10 point VAS scale)
Exclusion Criteria:
1. Fixed structural cause of nasal congestion (moderate or severe septal deviation, moderate or severe nasal valve collapse, Grade 3-4 polyp)
2. Inability to read and understand English
3. Allergic sensitivity to silicone or any other component of device
4. History of severe nose bleeding within last 3 months
5. Anticoagulation (Aspirin is acceptable)
6. Known pregnancy
7. Current nasal crusting or ulceration revealed on rhinoscopy
8. Inability to perform treatment due to underlying medical condition
9. Topical decongestant use in last week

facility.name: Sinus Center - Medical Univesity of South Carolina

patient_data.ipd_description: Not Applicable. We plan to publish this study.

provided_document.document_type: Study Protocol and Statistical Analysis Plan

measure.title: visual analogue scale (VAS)
measure.description: The visual analog scale (VAS) for rhinosinusitis is used to evaluate the total severity. The subject is asked to indicate on a VAS the answer to the question: "How troublesome are your symptoms of rhinosinusitis?" Subject will assess Nasal symptoms using a 10 cm Visual Analog Scale for each symptom, 0=not troublesome and 10 = the worst imaginable. The disease can be divided into Mild, Moderate and Severe based on total severity VAS score (0 to 10 cm): Mild = VAS 0-3 Moderate = VAS > 3-7 Severe = VAS > 7-10

measure.title: Total Nasal Symptom Score (TNSS)
measure.description: Change from baseline to week 6 in subject congestion symptom severity, as measured by the Total Nasal Symptom Score (TNSS, range 0-3). Where 0 indicates no symptoms, a score of 1 for mild symptoms that are easily tolerated, 2 for awareness of symptoms which are bothersome but tolerable and 3 is reserved for severe symptoms that are hard to tolerate and interfere with daily activity. TNSS is calculated by adding the score for each of the symptoms to a total out of 15.

measure.title: Nasal Obstruction and Septoplasty Effectiveness (NOSE) score
measure.description: Change from baseline to week 6 in subject nasal congestion severity, as measured by the Nasal Obstruction and Septoplasty Effectiveness Scale (NOSE Scale). The NOSE scale is a subject-completed questionnaire that consists of 5 questions. Each item is rated as follows: 0=not a problem, 1=very mild problem, 2=moderate problem, 3=fairly bad problem, 4=severe problem. The total score can range from 0-100, 0 being the best and 100 being the worst.

measure.title: 22-item Sino-Nasal Outcome Test (SNOT-22)
measure.description: Change from baseline to week 6 in subject symptoms and functioning, as measured by Sinonasal Outcome Test - 22 (SNOT-22). SNOT-22 is a subject-completed questionnaire that consists of 22 questions. Each item is rated as follows: 0=no problem, 1=very mild problem, 2=mild or slight problem, 3=moderate problem, 4=severe problem, 5=problem as bad as it can be. The total score can range from 0-110, 0 being the best and 110 being the worst.

outcome.title: Change in Total Nasal Symptom Score (TNSS) at 4 to 6 Weeks
outcome.description: Change from baseline to week 6 in subject congestion symptom severity, as measured by the Total Nasal Symptom Score (TNSS, range 0-3). Where 0 indicates no symptoms, a score of 1 for mild symptoms that are easily tolerated, 2 for awareness of symptoms which are bothersome but tolerable and 3 is reserved for severe symptoms that are hard to tolerate and interfere with daily activity. TNSS is calculated by adding the score for each of the symptoms to a total out of 15.
outcome.time_frame: Total Nasal Symptom Score (TNSS) at 4 to 6 Weeks

certain_agreements.pi_employee: All Principal Investigators ARE employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
